description.narrative: The U.S. government provides significant assistance to accelerate Ghana's transition towards an established lower middle-income country status. U.S. assistance supports Ghana's efforts to solidify its position as a leader in a region unfortunately known for civil strife, poor governance and economic stagnation. U.S. assistance to Ghana is supported through a number of presidential initiatives and foreign assistance priorities, including Feed the Future (FTF), the Global Health Initiative, and Power Africa, as well as through support from the regional Trade Africa program. To support Ghana to achieve its development goals, U.S. assistance will promote good governance; improve health care; strengthen the basic education system; expand agricultural production; increase access to power; and enhance the capacity of the Ghanaian armed forces.

description.narrative: The Ebola Virus Disease outbreak of 2014 - 2015 significantly affected the advances that Guinea has made since democracy took root in 2010. Though the epidemic was largely brought under control late by 2015, Guinea will continue to face the social, economic, and health consequences of the Ebola outbreak. The Ebola outbreak highlighted the weak governance that has crippled the well-being and growth of the country for decades. Dysfunctional government administration, pervasive public corruption, and rampant infectious diseases exacerbated by malnutrition are among Guinea's challenges. Environmental sanitation is poor, cholera and typhoid epidemics occur regularly, along with pervasive malaria and diarrhea that kill many, especially children. U.S. assistance will increase the availability of quality health services and improve food security, with a particular focus on improving delivery of health services, strengthening health systems, and encouraging communities to access health services. Assistance will also target civil society, media programming, and strategic security sector reform to encourage the development of a rule of law culture in Guinea, which is critical to reshaping the country's institutions. The United States seeks to accomplish these objectives through effective collaboration with the Government of Guinea (GOG), other donors, local non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and the private sector.

description.narrative: The Ebola Virus Disease outbreak of 2014 - 2015 dramatically affected the progress that Liberia had made towards sustained development since the end of the 14-year civil war. While Liberia demonstrated strong leadership and partnership with the international community in successfully controlling the outbreak, the emergency highlighted institutional flaws, which undermined the population's trust in the Government of Liberia (GOL). Though the disease outbreak was largely brought under control by mid-2015, Liberia continues to suffer the social, economic, and health consequences of a national crisis that cut off access to basic services, slowed domestic trade, and curtailed international travel and commerce for an extended period. U.S. assistance in FY 2017 will continue to be an essential part of helping to bring the country back onto a sustainable development path. The United States will continue to promote a secure, stable Liberia with enhanced rule of law, broad-based economic development, and improved education and health systems.

description.narrative: Despite experiencing the most severe Ebola Virus disease outbreak ever recorded, Sierra Leone has made significant gains in consolidating peace, promoting democracy at local and national levels, encouraging economic growth and facilitating overall engagement in development processes. Nevertheless, Sierra Leone continues to grapple with serious development challenges, such as entrenched corruption, weak governmental institutions, high unemployment, slow economic growth and inadequate social services, including water and electricity. U.S. assistance will improve the daily lives of Sierra Leoneans through strategic investments in agriculture and health services, including farmer training, nutrition programs and policy reform. U.S. assistance will also target civil society and media programming, security sector reform, and rule of law programs. The U.S. government will accomplish these goals through close collaboration with the Government of Sierra Leone (GOSL), other donors, local non-governmental organizations, and the private sector.

title.narrative: Ebola Response Support – Health Workers Salaries Payment

description.narrative: (Liberia): This activity will provide short term emergency financing for salaries for key civil servant health workers of the Government of Liberia who are paid a Liberian Dollar salary by direct bank transfer. Paying civil servant salaries for health care workers on Government of Liberia (GOL) payroll will enable the GOL to create some fiscal space to ease burdens in other areas of the Ebola response. The GOL will use its normal payroll procedures to pay the salaries of MoH civil servants, including those paid by direct bank transfer. The GOL will then present USAID with documentation sufficient to validate payment to the civil servants receiving direct bank transfer. USAID will then reimburse approved costs to the Ministry of Finance. A minimum of 3,710 health care civil servants will receive their regular monthly salary, and continue to work full time in accordance with their employment agreement, for the duration of the grant.

title.narrative: Children and Youth Education Response Activity CYERA

description.narrative: (Democratic Republic of the Congo): Due to existing crises 3.5 million Congolese primary school children are not in school. Adolescent girls in conflict and displaced settings are especially at risk of sexual and gender-based violence, which often leads to drop out and further vulnerability. To address these challenges, TBD Children and Youth Education Response Activity (CYERA) will increase children's access to education, create safer learning environments, and improve the quality of teaching and learning in schools. CYERA will target children and youth (both girls and boys) living in crisis- and conflict-affected communities of Ituri, North Kivu, and South Kivu. CYERA is designed to deliver rapid education services in other provinces (e.g., Haut Uele, Tanganyika, Kasaï Central) if and when requested based on anticipated needs. Equal access to quality education can create pathways for greater economic growth, improved health outcomes, sustained democratic governance, and more peaceful and resilient societies. CYERA will build the resilience of Congolese children and youth so they propel the DRC on its own journey to self- reliance. Additionally, FY 2020 resources will be provided as grants to local organizations focused on child protection and education. These grants will help a new set of domestic implementing partners develop their technical and administrative capacity to deliver such programs in the future without an international intermediary. .CYERA will advance CDCS DO 2 by strengthening education services delivery, increasing access to education services, and improving collaboration between education actors. CYERA will also contribute to TO 3 by strengthening individual and community resilience through education, by strengthening the institutional resilience of local actors, and by restoring services for crisis- and conflict-affected populations, including those impacted by COVID and Ebola... ........

title.narrative: Global Health Supply Chain-Technical Assistance IDIQ, Task Order to Strengthen Cote d'Ivoire Health Commodity Supply Chain System.

description.narrative: The purpose of this task order is to provide expert technical assistance to strengthen Cote d'Ivoire health commodity supply chain system. The task order will address the health commodity technical assistance needs of USAID programs as well as those of other USG agencies, the government of Cote d'Ivoire, and non-governmental organizations. Current USG programs in Cote dIvoire target HIVAIDS, tuberculosis, family planning, reproductive health, malaria, neglected tropical diseases, and various Global Health Security Agenda diseases such as Ebola, avian influenza and other potential pandemic diseases.

title.narrative: Integrated Governance Activity

description.narrative: (Democratic Republic of the Congo): The Integrated Governance Activity (IGA) will strengthen governance in targeted service delivery entities and enhance the social contract between citizens and their government in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). The activity will empower citizens, civil society, and the private sector to hold government institutions accountable through improved oversight of public service delivery in health, education and economic growth. The activity will emphasize public financial management, mostly promoting participatory budget processes and citizen oversight and will complement ongoing Congolese and other efforts to ensure that local, provincial, and national revenues are managed more transparently and employed to address citizen priorities, especially in Ebola affected areas. Assistance will include government entities. .IGA contributes to Mission Objective 1.2 by empowering national-level institutions to more effectively implement their mandates and Mission Objective 2.1 by improving public service delivery in health, education and economic growth. IGA works to advance the Administration's policy priority of protecting America's security at home and abroad by addressing a key driver of instability in the DRC - poor governance and weak institutions. By doing so, IGA will also support efforts to respond to the Ebola outbreak by addressing the underlying governance weaknesses that hinder the Ebola response. ... .

title.narrative: Partnership for Advancing Community-based Services (PACS)

description.narrative: (Liberia): FY 2018 funds will be used to increase the availability and utilization of community-based health, social welfare, and WASH services in three counties and build the capacity of MOH (at both central and county levels) and local organizations to deliver these services. The activity will also generate information and behavior change strategies at the community level to increase demand for the quality health services and encourage accountability of community based groups and associations. Funds will strengthen systems for supportive supervision at the community level and strengthen the use of the Community Based Information System to improve overall quality of community health services. These interventions will be supported through the implementation of an integrated package of community based services including the management of malaria, diarrhea and acute respiratory infections in children under five through the newly trained Community Health Assistants (CHAs). In addition to increasing access to health services, this activity will support the MOH to build management and operational capacities within the health system. Through local CSOs, community structures are strengthened to improve linkages between health facilities and communities. With FY 2018 funds, USAID will strengthen the internal management systems of local CSOs to foster effective participation in governance, advocacy, and service provision at local and national levels thereby increasing their effectiveness in executing their roles in the health system. USAID will also support Community Events Based Surveillance (CEBS), to strengthen epidemic preparedness and response activities. This activity will contribute to the sustainability of community based surveillance systems which were established during the Ebola crisis. The activity will support training for volunteers and immigration personnel at various borders and crossing points on CEBS and Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) protocols.

Objectives for Liberia: The specific objectives of the activity are to: Build local capacity to implement and manage programs; Increase availability of sustainable and quality community based health services; Promote demand for and provision of community health and social (child) welfare services; and Improve safe water supply and sanitation at the community level.

title.narrative: Citizens' Involvement in Health Governance (CIHG)
La participation des citoyens dans le gouvernement de santé (CIHG)

description.narrative: (Guinea): The purpose of the activity is to improve citizens' understanding and participation in system reform. The activity's key focus is increasing the accountability of elected and appointed officials both at national and local levels, expanding opportunities for citizen involvement and oversight, and expanding public dialogue. Citizens will be aware of health reform programs underway and will be sensitive to the issues affecting Ebola survivors and care givers, through discussions on disease prevention and oversight, advocacy on health systems reform and recovery. Specifically, activities include training and technical assistance that would forge new coalitions among government entities, private sector, including civil society organizations, the media and community based organizations. ..These are key elements to improve the effectiveness of Guinea's democratic system and to rebuild public trust in public health and thereby accelerate post-Ebola recovery.

(La Guinée) : Le but de l'activité est d'améliorer la compréhension et la participation des citoyens à la réforme de système. Le foyer principal de l'activité augmente la responsabilité des fonctionnaires élus et désignés à national et aux niveaux locaux, augmentant des occasions pour la participation et la supervision de citoyen, et augmentant le dialogue public. Les citoyens se rendront compte des programmes de réforme de santé en cours et seront sensibles aux questions affectant des survivants d'Ebola et des donateurs de soin, par des discussions sur la prévention et la supervision de la maladie, la recommandation sur la réforme de systèmes de santé et la relance. Spécifiquement, les activités incluent la formation et l'assistance technique qui forgerait de nouvelles coalitions parmi les entités de gouvernement, secteur privé, y compris des organismes de société civile, les médias et la communauté a basé des organismes. Ce sont des éléments clé pour améliorer l'efficacité du système démocratique de la Guinée et pour reconstruire la confiance publique dans la santé publique et pour accélérer de ce fait la relance de courrier-Ebola.

title.narrative: FFP Cash Learning Partnership Ebola Study

description.narrative: (USAID Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance (DCHA)): DCHA's Office of Food for Peace commissioned this study to document and disseminate lessons learned from FFP's response to the Ebola crisis in West Africa from 2014-2016. FFP's response included the innovative use of cash and electronic food vouchers through mobile phones. Lessons from this experience can inform future responses to similar epidemic situations.

description.narrative: The WFP Regional EMOP seeks to address the acute food insecurity needs of individuals, households, and communities directly affected by the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) epidemic that is affecting Liberia, Guinea, and Sierr Leone.

title.narrative: Federação internacional da cruz vermelha e do crescente vermelho (IFRC)
Fédération internationale de la Croix-Rouge et du croissant rouge (FICR)
International Federation of Red Cross and Crescent Societies (IFRC) Umbrella PIO Grant

description.narrative: (Santé globale d'USAID (GH)) :. Le but de cet accord est d'atténuer le health.impact des maladies infectieuses et d'autres enjeux de santé publique par la santé à caractère communautaire holistique à grande échelle de delivery.of programmant en quelque sorte la durabilité de that.maximizes et vise le plus vulnérable et l'at-risk.populations. Cette concession fournira un moyen flexible et simple pour que les unités d'USAID.operating accèdent à la fédération internationale des sièges sociaux de Croix-Rouge et de Red.Crescent (FICR) et de l'expertise de bureau local pour soutenir un wide.range des programmes de santé globaux. Par des rapports de travail activité-spécifiques, les missions de .USAID et/ou les unités de fonctionnement de siège social pourront aux interventions de develop.customized avec la FICR. Généralement les activités peuvent inclure, mais are.not limité à : soutenant la distribution des campagnes insecticide-traitées des filets through.mass, renforçant des capacités universelles à caractère communautaire d'état de préparation, .and fournissant des mesures de réponse de maladie infectieuse pour disease.outbreaks prioritaire (par exemple, Ebola) de réduire au minimum l'impact sur les communautés affectées.

(Saúde global de USAID (GH)):. A finalidade deste acordo é abrandar o health.impact de doenças infecciosas e de outros problemas de saúde públicos com a saúde comunidade-baseada holística em grande escala de delivery.of que programa de um modo a sustentabilidade de that.maximizes e visa o mais vulnerável e at-risk.populations. Esta concessão fornecerá uns meios flexíveis e simples para que as unidades de USAID.operating alcancem a federação internacional das matrizes da cruz vermelha e do Red.Crescent (IFRC) e da experiência do gabinete no terreno para apoiar um wide.range de programas de saúde globais. Com as indicações de trabalho atividade-específicas, as missões de .USAID e/ou as unidades de funcionamento da sede poderão às intervenções de develop.customized com IFRC. Geralmente, as atividades podem incluir, mas are.not limitado a: apoiando a distribuição de campanhas inseticida-tratadas das redes through.mass, reforçando capacidades pandêmicas comunidade-baseadas da prontidão, .and que fornece medidas da resposta da doença infecciosa para disease.outbreaks prioritário (por exemplo, Ebola) minimizar o impacto nas comunidades afetadas.

To mitigate health impact of infectious diseases and other public health issues through delivery of large scale holistic community based health programming in a manner that maximizes sustainability and targets the most vulnerable and at-risk populations.

title.narrative: USAID/OFDA CONTRACT FOR WEST AFRICA EBOLA

description.narrative: USAID/OFDA CONTRACT FOR WEST AFRICA EBOLA

title.narrative: Clinical and Non-Clinical Management of Ebola Treatment Units (CNMETU)

description.narrative: On October 31, 2014, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) awarded PAE a sole-source contract to provide services in Liberia to support the U.S. governments response to the outbreak. The contract, called Clinical and Nonclinical Management of Ebola Treatment Units (CNMETU), ran from November 2014 to August 2015. PAE partnered with Aspen Medical, which provided clinical services, while PAE provided the necessary infrastructure and logistical services. PAEs experience working in Africa (particularly its work over the past decade in Liberia) and Aspen Medicals in-country operational medical capability offered a team with the experience and capabilities necessary to operate in a challenging environment.

title.narrative: Monitoring and Evaluation IQC Task Order - Ensure Evaluation and Monitoring Activities examine USAID-Funded Ebola Recovery Interventions

description.narrative: The purpose of this task order is to ensure these evaluations and monitoring activities will examine USAID-funded Ebola recovery interventions in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone from March 2014 until December 2019. This task order will involve capturing, aggregating, and reporting on all recovery activities performance and impact toward achieving established Pillar II macro-level objectives as stated in the Africa Ebola Unit (AEU) Strategic Framework and the monitoring and evaluation (ME) Results Framework (See Annex I- Results Framework). The Task Order will include providing expert analysis of Pillar II country-level sustainability of achievements and informs adjustments to long-term country activities at the Development Objectives level as outlined in the Country Development Cooperative Strategy (CDCS) and the Integrated Country Strategy (ICS.)
